key_learning_points.key_learning_point: In the introduction, make reference to the writers’ over-arching messages and the shifts or consistency of their tone.
Use the first paragraph of analysis to compare how the writers establish their ideas in the opening.
Use the middle paragraph to compare how the writers’ attitude/tone shifts and the exploration of structural features.
Use your final paragraph to compare the final messages that the writers convey on the topic through devices.

keywords.description: something so important it affects all other areas- in English, we refer to a writer’s overarching idea
when applied to writing, this refers to a change in the writer’s perspective
a form of a verb which is a direct command or order
the words, ideas, feelings or concepts we associate with a word or symbol

pupil_lesson_outcome: I can write a comparison of attitudes.

misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.misconception: I must always identify language devices.
misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.response: Although it is useful to analyse language devices used by a writer, analysing individual words can be just as effective. For example, there are lots of words that could form the basis of good analysis in Day's article ("devastation", "disaster").

teacher_tips.teacher_tip: Students will need to have read both of the extracts in this lesson. You will need to spend some time reading if they haven't previously encountered them.

title: Writing a comparison of attitudes

key_learning_points.key_learning_point: Take a clear stance for or against the statement - alternative arguments should be refuted at least once in the piece.
Contrast creates a robust sense of a writer’s perspective, by demonstrating feeling towards all angles of an argument.
Use sarcasm to point out the flaws of the opposition, in an emotive and personalised way.
Carefully sequence and vary subtle and dramatic shifts in tone, to draw reactions from the reader.

keywords.description: the a language a writer uses to communicate their perspective- this could be sarcastic, hopeful or fun etc.
the use of irony to show contempt for something: in an opinion piece we can use sarcasm to deal with opposing views
to prove something wrong or untrue
something that spoils something or has a very bad effect
a rhetorical device used to emphasise the difference between two things

pupil_lesson_outcome: I can use voice effectively in non-fiction writing.

misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.misconception: Refuting counter-arguments is enough to create an impact.
misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.response: Although it is good practice to refute counter-arguments, we can also use language devices when we do so to make these even more powerful.

teacher_tips.teacher_tip: This lesson focuses on writing an opinion piece about fairs and festivals. You may wish to change the question stem so that it better fits the needs or context of your class.

title: Crafting a voice in nonfiction writing

key_learning_points.key_learning_point: The status of the recipient defined in the question will indicate the level of formality required in the writing.
Take a clear stance for or against the statement; alternative arguments should be refuted at least once in the piece.
Identifying the recipient offers the opportunity to refer to their role, involvement and action that they could take.
Discourse markers provide useful influential language around your opinion.

keywords.description: to prove something wrong or untrue
words and phrases that help signpost our ideas (e.g. firstly or for example)
a type of language that is used for important or official pieces of writing
the language a writer uses to communicate their perspective, this could be sarcastic, hopeful or fun etc.
something that spoils something or has a bad effect

pupil_lesson_outcome: I can write a letter in which I express a clear point of view.

misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.misconception: All discourse markers are broadly similar.
misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.response: Discourse markers are actually very diverse with a whole range of different uses. This lesson focuses explicitly on those appropriate for refuting counter-arguments.

teacher_tips.teacher_tip: This lesson contains a transactional writing task related to whether fairs and festivals should be banned. You could change this with a different task more appropriate to the needs of your class. The lesson's tasks and activities would still be appropriate.

title: Crafting a clear point of view in non-fiction writing

key_learning_points.key_learning_point: Make three linked points about the writer’s attitudes or perspectives, supported by a range of evidence from both texts.
Contextual information can give a greater understanding of a writer's perspective.
Use adjectives to track changes in the writers’ perspectives from the start to the end of the text.
Correlative conjunctions and comparatives can be used to write comparative topic sentences.

keywords.description: the way someone thinks or feels about a particular thing
background information that can help us understand a text further (e.g. when it was written)
when applied to writing, this refers to a change in the writer’s perspective
correlative conjunctions work in pairs to join words, phrases or clauses (e.g. neither/nor)
comparative conjunctions are used to show a difference between two ideas (e.g. ‘whereas’ )

pupil_lesson_outcome: I can precisely structure a comparison of attitudes.

misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.misconception: As long as I use adjectives to qualify a writer's perspective then that is good writing.
misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.response: Although a good starting point, the best writing will ensure that adjectives are used to evaluate shifts in a writer's perspective across a piece.

teacher_tips.teacher_tip: Students will need time to read both of the extracts if they haven't read them in a previous lesson.

title: Structuring a comparison of attitudes

key_learning_points.key_learning_point: Precise evaluative adjectives express an interpretation in relation to the question.
Define one over-arching point about the way language is used and use three smaller points to support.
Select evidence that explores patterns and contrasts within the language.
Use short judicious quotations of 1-3 words to support analysis.
Create an over-arching sense of the writer’s purpose or underlying message - show how this is conveyed through language.

keywords.description: adjectives we can use in our writing to give a judgement about what we are reading
something so important it affects all other areas- in English, we refer to a writer’s overarching idea
showing good judgement- when applied to evidence, it means well-chosen to the point you are making
when referring to quotes, it means quotes that form part of your own writing
a condition causing someone to have a shorter height as a result of a genetic or medical condition

lesson_outline.lesson_outline: Reading 'My life as a little person'

pupil_lesson_outcome: I can plan for cohesively written language analysis.

misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.misconception: Language devices - like similes and metaphors - are more appropriate for analysis in stories and narrative fiction.
misconceptions_and_common_mistakes.response: Creative non-fiction writing can be rich in methods and language devices - it can offer just as many opportunities for analysis as a more traditionally creative piece.

teacher_tips.teacher_tip: This lesson is focused on an article written by Cara Reedy - an American journalist who writes about her experiences with dwarfism. You may wish to build context further by exploring further resources (videos/articles) about Reedy and her condition.

title: Planning for effective language analysis
